author: By Roger Cohen
title: Le Pen Closer Than Ever to the French Presidency (and to Putin)
description: As elections approach Sunday, the far-right candidate is linked to the Russian president by a web of financial ties and a history of support that has hardly dimmed despite the war in Ukraine.
content: PARIS — When Europe’s far-right leaders gathered in Madrid in January, they had no problem finding unity on the issues they hold dear, whether cracking down on immigrants or upholding “European Christian ideals.” But as Russian troops massed on the Ukrainian border, they were divided on one issue: the threat posed by President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Neil Vigdor
title: Marjorie Taylor Greene Denies ‘Insurrectionist’ Charge in Court
description: In an extraordinary administrative law hearing, the Georgia representative was forced to defend her actions surrounding the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia, on Friday repeated false claims of widespread fraud in the 2020 presidential election as she defended her actions surrounding the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, in an extraordinary hearing that asked whether she should be labeled an “insurrectionist” and barred from office under the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: In ‘Gaslit,’ a Victim of Watergate and History Finds Rescue
description: Starring Julia Roberts and Sean Penn, the Starz limited series focuses on Martha Mitchell, whose life was ruined by the scandal.
content: With her flamboyant public persona and her proximity to one of Hollywood’s favorite American political scandals, Martha Mitchell seems like a natural figure on which to center a historical screen drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: vernal
description: This word has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word vernal has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 30 in “Gnocchi, Leeks, Soupy Greens: What Else Do You Need?” by Melissa Clark:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: An Afrofuturist Trip to the Lunarverse
description: The choreographer and dancer Shamel Pitts’s “Black Hole: Trilogy and Triathlon” at New York Live Arts is stylish and sincere.
content: Even before “Black Hole: Trilogy and Triathlon” begins, it is already in intriguing motion. As you take your seat at New York Live Arts, you can make out a bumpy mound on the floor of the darkened stage. The points of light that illuminate this blob circulate and swell, so it seems alive. Is something in there?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart
title: Jeffrey Epstein, a Rare Cello and an Enduring Mystery
description: A cello’s strange odyssey helps explain how the notorious Mr. Epstein surrounded himself with the world’s richest and most powerful men.
content: When Jeffrey Epstein died in jail in 2019, he took many secrets with him. One was how a sexual predator and college dropout managed to forge bonds with an astonishing number of the world’s richest and most powerful men, like Britain’s Prince Andrew and the crown prince of Saudi Arabia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: ‘It’s Time to Head for the Lifeboats’: Democratic Fatalism Intensifies
description: Strategists and pollsters are increasingly talking about limiting the party’s expected losses in November rather than how to gain new seats.
content: The collective mood of Democratic insiders has darkened appreciably in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachelle Bonja, Kaitlin Roberts, Sydney Harper, Anita Badejo, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: France’s Big Decision
description: This weekend, French voters will choose between two presidential candidates with profoundly different visions of the future.
content: When they go to the polls on Sunday, voters in France will be faced with the same two presidential candidates as 2017: Emmanuel Macron, the president and a polished centrist, and Marine Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Rally party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Tennessee Bill Would Force Drunken Drivers to Support Victims’ Children
description: The state’s legislature is believed to be the first to pass such a measure, covering cases in which the parent of a minor is killed. It will go to the governor for his signature.
content: The Tennessee General Assembly on Wednesday became what is believed to be the first state legislature to pass a bill that would require drunken drivers to pay child support if they kill the parent of a minor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: Umang Gupta, Who Paved Way for Indian Tech Executives, Dies at 73
description: He found success as an entrepreneur in Silicon Valley shortly after arriving there in 1978, then represented his fellow alumni from the Indian Institutes of Technology.
content: Umang Gupta, a Silicon Valley executive who helped drive two trends in business software while blazing a trail for Indian-born entrepreneurs, died on Tuesday at his home in San Mateo, Calif. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
title: The End of CNN+
description: Its abrupt closure is raising doubts about the crowded field of streaming services.
content: Yesterday, Warner Bros. Discovery announced it was shutting down CNN+, the extensively hyped but extremely short-lived streaming service. It will close on April 30, for a total run of less than five weeks. “Well, that was fast,” said Scott Galloway, a professor who was planning to host a CNN+ show on business. Quibi, the ill-fated video platform that was streaming’s previous cautionary tale, lasted seven months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Newman
title: Your Son Will Come Out Tomorrow: Randy Rainbow’s Memoir of Love, Turmoil and Trump
description: Rainbow made the nation laugh by setting witty political commentary to Broadway tunes. Now he has a memoir on his rise from theater kid lip-syncing in his bedroom to social media star.
content: When your name — your actual name — is Randy Rainbow, your career choices are limited. Bank president? Mafia don? Nope. Neurosurgeon? Probably not. If Tom Brady had been named Randy Rainbow, instead of heading to the N.F.L. Hall of Fame he might be banging out show tunes at a Chelsea piano bar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Mady Camara
title: Taking Senegalese Soccer to New Heights, With Pride and Style
description: Aliou Cissé, one of the best of a new generation of African coaches, has reinvented Senegal’s national team and given the country a new sense of patriotism. His next goal: the World Cup.
content: DIAMNIADIO, Senegal — Standing on the sidelines of Senegal’s brand-new national stadium, Aliou Cissé, the biggest fan of his own team, waved his arms at 50,000 fans, exhorting them to cheer even louder, his signature dreadlocks bouncing on his shoulders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Ukraine needs up to $7 billion in support per month, Zelensky says.
description: Ukraine has suffered $550 billion in losses from the war, President Volodymyr Zelensky told the World Bank on Thursday.
content: Ukrainian officials on Thursday met with leaders abroad to call for additional financial support as their country reels from devastating attacks from Russian forces and a disrupted economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin M.F. Platt
title: The Profound Irony of Canceling Everything Russian
description: Those who react to the war in Ukraine by canceling everything Russian are in danger of falling into a familiar brand of nationalist thinking.
content: Within days of the start of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in late February, the canceling and boycotting of Russian cultural events in Europe and North America began. Cultural organizations broke ties with Russian performers and artists. Two of the world’s most revered Russian musical artists — the conductor Valery Gergiev and the soprano Anna Netrebko — had their performances in multiple countries canceled. The repercussions have reached artists and works with no direct connection to President Vladimir Putin or his agenda, like the 20-year-old Russian pianist Alexander Malofeev, who had openly denounced the invasion, whose debut concert tour in Canada was called off. The Polish National Opera even canceled performances of Mussorgsky’s “Boris Godunov.” The list goes on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How Much Do Antidepressants Help, Really?
description: While the drugs are widely used, a new study sheds light on how little is known about their long-term benefits.
content: The more popular antidepressants become, the more questions they raise. The drugs are one of the most widely prescribed types of medications in the United States, with more than one out of eight Americans over 18 having recently taken them, according to a survey from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Yet we know very little about how well antidepressants work over the long term, and especially how they affect overall quality of life, experts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: N.Y.C. places dozens of school employees on unpaid leave, saying they used fake vaccine cards.
description: Since September, the department has required all employees to provide proof of vaccination.
content: The New York City Department of Education this week notified dozens of school employees that they would be placed on unpaid leave effective Monday, after it said law enforcement alerted the department that they had provided false proof of coronavirus vaccination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘The Northman’ Wasn’t Easy to Make. But That’s How Robert Eggers Likes It.
description: The director explains why he sought out such difficult conditions, why he won’t talk with an actor about a character’s back story and why the box office matters.
content: Is Robert Eggers an endangered species?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Los Angeles County says masks are still required on public transportation, citing the C.D.C.
description: The move is a departure from California’s mask rules, which were relaxed this week after a federal judge struck down a nationwide mask mandate on public transit.
content: Los Angeles County announced on Thursday that it would continue requiring people to wear masks on all public transit and in airports, railway stations and other transportation hubs, embracing guidance from federal health authorities that has been stymied by a legal battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How a California Disaster Inspired the First Earth Day
description: A 1969 oil spill off the shore of Santa Barbara helped serve as a catalyst for environmental action.
content: Happy Earth Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein, Kenneth P. Vogel and Ryan Mac
title: Donald Trump’s Newest Problem: Elon Musk
description: Mr. Musk’s plan for a Twitter takeover adds to the problems facing the former president’s nascent Truth Social network.
content: Truth Social is slow and clunky. Its audience participation remains low. Two top executives have left. And the merger that could bring $1.3 billion in desperately needed cash to former President Donald J. Trump’s social media project seems far from completion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
title: Mosque Explosion Kills 33 as Deadly Week in Afghanistan Continues
description: The blast in Kunduz Province, in the north, was the latest in a series of attacks reminiscent of the past two decades of war.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — An explosion at a Sufi mosque in northern Afghanistan on Friday killed more than 30 people and wounded dozens of others, a Taliban official said, continuing a bloody week in Afghanistan that has been reminiscent of the past 20 years of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone and Zachary Woolfe
title: One Night, Several String Quartet Premieres
description: The JACK Quartet and the Danish String Quartet presented new works that nodded to the past and spoke to the present.
content: On Thursday evening, two eminent string quartets presented premieres in New York. At Merkin Hall, the JACK Quartet unveiled Patricia Alessandrini’s “A Complete History of Music (Volume 1),” Khyam Allami’s “Ma-a a-ba ud me-na-gin Ma-a di-di-in” and George Lewis’s “String Quartet 4.5.” Not far away, at Zankel Hall, the Danish String Quartet paired Schubert’s “Death and the Maiden” with Lotta Wennäkoski’s new “Pige.” Our critics were at both events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy Mandell
title: He Had a ‘Hunch’ They’d Get Hitched
description: When David Funchess first met Janelle Clark at church 15 years ago, he somehow knew that the two would end up together.
content: When Janelle Ashley Clark accompanied her friend Tiara Lewis to a 2007 service at the Resurrection Deliverance Church International in Yonkers, N.Y., she encountered a “tall, handsome and very talented” man playing the piano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: France issues an international arrest warrant for Carlos Ghosn.
description: Prosecutors say the disgraced auto tycoon channeled millions of euros in Renault funds through an Omani car distributor for personal use, including the purchase of a 120-foot yacht.
content: PARIS — French prosecutors issued an international arrest warrant on Friday for Carlos Ghosn, the former chief executive of Nissan and Renault who is living as a fugitive from the Japanese justice system, as part of an investigation into alleged abuse of corporate assets and money laundering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Finding Love on a 14-Hour Layover
description: Between flights to and from Munich in September 2016, Andrea Mendoza visited a beer hall in the city, where she met and instantly bonded with Victor Aguilera.
content: Despite being raised on different continents and residing in different countries, Andrea Mendoza and Victor Aguilera were not deterred from pursuing a relationship after they met in Munich during Oktoberfest in September 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: The Office Bully Won’t Win
description: There is one upside to the silent treatment: You don’t have to listen to a toxic co-worker.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: ‘Hangmen,’ Offering the Last Word in Gallows Humor
description: Martin McDonagh’s rollicking comedy about capital punishment, now on Broadway, feels like a perfect fit for our unjust times.
content: Welcome to Broadway’s fleurs-du-mal moment, a rare blossoming of funny plays on deeply unfunny subjects. At Circle in the Square, there’s “American Buffalo,” about creeping criminality; at the Friedman, “How I Learned to Drive,” about pedophilia; at Studio 54, “The Minutes,” about white triumphalism. In all of them, comedy is a top note, perfuming the odor of rot underneath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Djeneba Aduayom and Charley Locke
title: 6 Kids Speak Out Against Hair Discrimination
description: They talked to The New York Times for Kids about being singled out at school for how they wear their hair. Now they’re fighting for legislation so other kids won’t go through the same thing.
content: One day last spring, Jett Hawkins, 5, asked his mom to braid his hair for him. He loved the way it looked: “I was so proud and happy,” says Jett, who lives in Chicago. But when he got to school, his mother says, an administrator called her and told her that his hairstyle had broken a school policy that banned students from wearing braids, locs and twists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Starting Over as Friends Paved the Way for Lasting Romance
description: After dating for a couple of months, Elizabeth Berman and Richard Fiedotin broke it off to forge a friendship first.
content: On their first date at a San Francisco restaurant in April 2014, enough wine flowed and sparks flew between Elizabeth Krasney Berman and Richard Alan Fiedotin that the two soon found themselves “giggling like teenagers at the bar,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Emily St. John Mandel
description: A conversation with the novelist Emily St. John Mandel
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Emily St. John Mandel. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Barry’ Is Back. Here’s What You Need to Know.
description: The HBO drama, starring Bill Hader as a hit man trying to start over as an actor, has been away for three years, so here’s a refresher ahead of Season 3.
content: Because HBO’s Emmy-winning drama “Barry” has been on a pandemic-related hiatus for three full years, even the show’s devoted fans may not remember where the story left off at the end of Season 2, back in May 2019. So here is a quick refresher on how that finale ended: The ex-Marine and contract killer Barry Berkman slaughtered dozens of gangsters from various foreign mobs, while trying and failing to murder a man who betrayed him. Oh, and he might be on the verge of becoming a movie star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Covid Drugs Save Lives, but Americans Can’t Get Them
description: Once again, a dysfunctional health care system has hindered our pandemic response.
content: Almost two months after President Biden promised to make lifesaving drugs against Covid widely available to Americans, the medications remain hard to get for many, despite supplies, leaving large numbers of Americans to face increased risks of avoidable death and serious illness.
source.name: The New York Times

title: People Cope With Tragedy by Writing Poems. Maybe They Shouldn’t.
description: And other letters to the editor.
content: As we reported in our April 17 poetry issue, shortly after the Titanic sank on April 15, 1912, readers began sending verses to the paper — terrible ones, it seems. A few days later, The Times tried to quash these amateur poets by printing a notice which read, in part, “We do wish to state, very, very gently, that one of the most difficult tasks a real poet, experienced and skilled in the practice of his art, could undertake would be to write an adequate and fitting poem on the loss of the Titanic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By R. O. Blechman
title: R. O. Blechman: ‘April Was Not Cruel to T.S. Eliot’
description: A graphic ode to a founding father of literary modernism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In Polarized Texas, Rare Accord: A Hispanic Mother Shouldn’t Be Executed
description: The execution of Melissa Lucio would be the first of a Hispanic woman in Texas. New evidence casts doubt on her conviction.
content: HOUSTON — In less than a week, Texas is set to execute Melissa Lucio, a mother of 14 who was convicted of murder in the death of her 2-year-old daughter more than a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: After Hundreds of Emails, a First Date
description: Before Hannah Cha agreed to date Anthony Elfering, the two had a monthlong email exchange to get to know each other better.
content: Hannah Cha and Anthony Kim Elfering met in quintessential rom-com fashion: They were seated next to one another at a wedding in January 2019, at which both also gave speeches; Ms. Cha as a friend of the bride, and Mr. Elfering as a friend of the groom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Can Sanctions Really Stop Putin?
description: There are limits to what economic sanctions are likely to achieve.
content: When Vladimir Putin ordered the invasion of Ukraine in February, trampling on the sovereignty of a neighbor, international sanctions were the best path forward for the United States and its allies to take. The ruthlessness and grave atrocities toward civilians that have ensued since only reinforce that call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: E.U. Takes Aim at Social Media’s Harms With Landmark New Law
description: The Digital Services Act would force Meta, Google and others to combat misinformation and restrict certain online ads. How European officials will wield it remains to be seen.
content: The European Union reached a deal on Saturday on landmark legislation that would force Facebook, YouTube and other internet services to combat misinformation, disclose how their services amplify divisive content and stop targeting online ads based on a person’s ethnicity, religion or sexual orientation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Are There Limits to Pitching Perfection? Roki Sasaki Will Find Out.
description: The Japanese phenom is expected to start Sunday, with a streak of 52 consecutive retired batters on the line.
content: Any time a pitcher returns to the mound after a no-hitter or perfect game, the name Johnny Vander Meer is evoked. In 1938, Vander Meer followed up one no-hitter with another in his next start for the Cincinnati Reds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Snyder
title: The War in Ukraine Has Unleashed a New Word
description: In a creative play on three different languages, Ukrainians identify an enemy: ‘ruscism.’
content: The City Council of Mariupol, Ukraine, was trying to make a point about mass death. Their city had been hit hardest by the Russian invasion, and thousands of corpses lay amid the rubble after weeks of urban warfare. After the revelation of Russian atrocities in Bucha and other cities in northern Ukraine, the elected representatives of the port city wished to remind the world that the scale of killing in the south was still higher. In dry and sober language, they described the fates of Mariupol residents. Occasionally, though, emotion slipped through: In passing, the council members referred to the Russian perpetrators by a term of condemnation that every Ukrainian knows, though it is not yet in the dictionaries and cannot (yet) be said in English: “рашизм.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Emily St. John Mandel on Time Travel, Parenting and the Apocalypse
description: The novelist explains why we secretly long for different worlds, and how post-apocalyptic fiction quells our grief.
content: “Station Eleven” by Emily St. John Mandel was published in 2014. That book imagined the world after a pandemic had wiped out, well, almost everyone. It’s a gorgeous novel with a particular emotional power: it helps you grieve a life you still have. But then came a real pandemic, not as lethal as the one Mandel imagined, but a shock nonetheless. And “Station Eleven” — already a beloved international best seller — found a second life. Mandel became known as a pandemic prophet. “Station Eleven” became an acclaimed HBO Max series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simran Hans
title: In ‘The Duke,’ Jim Broadbent Puts an Eccentric at the Center
description: The British actor has spent six decades seeking out carefully observed, often quirky characters. In his latest film, he’s also the lead.
content: LONDON — In Room 45 of the National Gallery here, Jim Broadbent surveyed Francisco de Goya’s portrait of the Duke of Wellington. It was not his first encounter with the painting. But, “I haven’t seen him next to Napoleon before,” he said, nodding toward Vernet’s study of the French emperor hanging nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Why Midterm Election Years Are Tough for the Stock Market
description: These months are historically the weakest for the market in a presidential term. Aside from coincidence, there are several possible explanations.
content: The stock market’s decline and the tightening of financial conditions that have accompanied it since the start of the year are unique to 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can you solve drought by piping water across the country?
description: Moving water from the East to the parched West would be astronomically difficult.
content: The idea of taking water from one community and giving it to another has some basis in American history. In 1913, Los Angeles opened an aqueduct to carry water from Owens Valley, 230 miles north of the city, to sustain its growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Some Home Buyers Turn to Alternative Financing as Other Options Dwindle
description: A new study found that even creditworthy shoppers may be unable to find traditional mortgages. But the arrangements often lack typical consumer protections.
content: Millions of American home shoppers have taken on risky and generally more costly alternative financing, in part because even creditworthy buyers may have trouble finding traditional mortgages for lower-priced properties, new research suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Harris
title: 4 Ways to Fortify Your Retirement Against Market Whims
description: So many factors cause volatility in the markets, making it tricky even for the experts to know what’s next. They still have ideas.
content: For every investor, the world has become a hard place. There’s volatility for stocks and bonds. Rising interest rates and inflation. Economic uncertainty from the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the persistent pandemic. But those who are retired, and those who are approaching retirement, are in special circumstances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Putin prematurely claims victory in Mariupol.
content: Speaking from Moscow, Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, said Russia had gained control of the devastated Ukrainian city of Mariupol, even as fighting continued. He publicly called off an assault on a final stronghold — a sprawling steel mill where 2,000 Ukrainian fighters are said to remain — in a stark display of the Kremlin’s desire to present a success to the Russian public. Follow the latest updates on the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: McCarthy’s Lie Puts G.O.P. Hypocrisy on Trump on Display
description: The Republican leader’s false claim that he never urged President Donald J. Trump to resign — disproved by an audio recording of the comments — drew little outrage from members of his party.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy’s denial of disparaging comments he made about President Donald J. Trump after the Capitol attack on Jan. 6, 2021, exposed a widely known but seldom seen phenomenon in Washington: the hypocrisy of Republicans who have privately scorned Mr. Trump while publicly defending him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Ukrainian Troops Dig In
description: Soldiers on the front lines vow to prevent Russia from pushing through.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Tony Award Nominations Postponed Because of Coronavirus Delays
description: The nominations will now be announced May 9, but the awards ceremony will remain, as scheduled, on June 12.
content: This year’s Tony Award nominations will be delayed by nearly a week, administrators of the awards said Friday, because enough actors have been out with coronavirus cases that it has become difficult for awards nominators to see all the eligible performances.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Florida Cuts Tax District for Disney
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 22, 2022.
content: “The impact on Disney is more symbolic than real money, though political theater is never great for stock sentiment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaya Laterman
title: Her Job? Planting Thousands of Trees Every Year in New York City.
description: Melinda Clancy, a procurement forester, describes why she selects maples for the Bronx and lilacs for Brooklyn.
content: The ambition of the project was what made it so memorable. The million trees program, started in the Bloomberg administration in 2007, helped the city better position itself to combat climate change. Now, all five borough presidents are pushing Mayor Eric Adams to add another million by 2030.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel, Aishvarya Kavi and Alyssa Lukpat
title: Suspect in Sniper-Style Shooting in Washington Kills Himself, Police Say
description: Four people were injured in the shooting near a busy corridor in the nation’s capital. The suspect apparently killed himself as the police prepared to enter a fifth-floor apartment from which he had fired more than 20 rounds, the police said.
content: A suspect who the police said had set up a tripod in an apartment along one of Washington’s busiest corridors and randomly fired more than 20 rounds, injuring four people, apparently killed himself Friday night as the police prepared to enter the apartment, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: A Site Holy to Jews and Muslims Returns as the Nexus of Conflict
description: The skirmishes between Palestinians and Israeli police at the Aqsa Mosque, known to Jews as Temple Mount, are laden with national and religious symbolism.
content: JERUSALEM — Clashes broke out Friday for the seventh time in eight days at the holiest site in Jerusalem, foregrounding how the site — sacred to both Jews and Muslims — has become the newest focus of a monthlong spasm in tensions across Israel and the occupied territories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Neil Vigdor
title: McCarthy Said Trump Acknowledged ‘Some Responsibility’ for Jan. 6
description: New audio captures what Representative Kevin McCarthy said to Republicans shortly after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
content: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the House Republican leader, told G.O.P. lawmakers in the days after the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol that former President Donald J. Trump acknowledged he bore “some responsibility” for what happened that day, new audio revealed on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Lefton
title: To Get to the Cubs, Seiya Suzuki Needed a New Idol
description: A surprising comparison from a veteran teammate led Suzuki to emulate Mike Trout. Thus far, the comparison seems apt.
content: MESA, Ariz. — Ichiro Suzuki is a sinewy 5 feet 11 inches and 170 pounds, while Mike Trout is a stout 6-2, 235. They represent wildly different body types and playing styles, but their unique abilities converged in influencing the career path of Seiya Suzuki.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Soak Up the Sun
description: Daniel Sheremeta makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — You have to appreciate a puzzle that opens with a helpful tip. LIFE HACKs — 1A in Daniel Sheremeta’s debut puzzle — are tricks or strategies that are meant to make life easier, or at least more productive and efficient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Maskless Flying
description: What might a more effective mask mandate look like?
content: On Sunday, I spent nearly five hours on an airplane, flying home from the West Coast. For long stretches of the flight, whenever the crew was serving food and drinks, many passengers were not wearing masks. Even when people did have their masks on, many wore them below their noses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘The Baby’ Review: That Kid’s a Monster. No, Literally.
description: In a horror comedy from HBO, a woman who never wanted a baby finds herself stuck with a little killer.
content: The star of “The Baby” doesn’t have any lines; his performance consists almost entirely of reaction shots. As adults die around him in increasingly baroque ways — a dive off a cliff, a pitchfork through the neck, a boulder on the car — he displays impressive range. He gurgles, coos and giggles, but he most often chooses a quizzical, slightly exasperated frown, as if to say, “You don’t honestly think I had anything to do with that, do you?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
title: Texas National Guard Soldier Feared Drowned in Rio Grande
description: The guardsman was trying to rescue a migrant woman in the river when he was swept away, according to Sheriff Tom Schmerber of Maverick County.
content: HOUSTON — A member of the Texas National Guard was missing and believed drowned in the Rio Grande on Friday while stationed along the river, as part of a mission ordered by Gov. Greg Abbott to help prevent illegal border crossings, according to two officials briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: As Europe Approves New Tech Laws, the U.S. Falls Further Behind
description: Federal privacy bills, security legislation and antitrust laws to address the power of the tech giants have all failed to advance in Congress, despite hand wringing and shows of bipartisan support.
content: In just the last few years, Europe has seen a sweeping law for online privacy take effect, approved far-reaching regulations to curb the dominance of the tech giants and on Saturday reached a deal on new legislation to protect its citizens from harmful online content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Frances Robles
title: Punishing Disney, DeSantis Signals a Lasting G.O.P. Brawl With Business
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s move to revoke the company’s special tax status in Florida showed how combative his party has grown toward corporations that are increasingly taking a stand on political issues.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis on Friday revoked Disney’s special tax and self-governing privileges in Florida, culminating an extraordinary clash between one of the Republican Party’s leading figures and a powerful company with deep historical ties to his state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Thompson
title: If a Rat Falls Into Your Bed, Call Your Lover’s Boyfriend
description: Hey, it worked for me!
content: The rustling of the curtains that cover my bedside window woke me around 4 a.m. I opened my eyes just in time to see a rat jump down from the windowsill onto my comforter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: How Nicolas Cage Parodies Himself in ‘Massive Talent’
description: Tom Gormican, the director of “The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent,” narrates a sequence featuring the star and Pedro Pascal.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: How a Race-Based Medical Formula Is Keeping Some Black Men in Prison
description: The formula, which helps estimate kidney health, has been discarded by many hospitals. But some judges still use it to decide whether to release those potentially endangered by Covid-19.
content: Last month, a federal judge in New Jersey considered the plea of an inmate who claimed his kidney problems made Covid-19 especially dangerous for him. The man, Maurice McPhatter, 49, was one of more than 20,000 federal prisoners who have sought early release during the pandemic. Thousands have been freed through that process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: A Surreal Feel at a Wartime Venice Biennale
description: While the cool contemporary art crowd strolled among the exhibits, Ukraine was being pummeled by missiles, and there was hardly a Russian in sight.
content: VENICE — “What happened to free speech in Italy?” shouted one of the 50 or so onlookers on Wednesday morning as a security guard stood in front of a lone antiwar protester at the Venice Biennale, trying to block out his message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Tina Brown Catches Up With Royal Intrigue in ‘The Palace Papers’
description: In her new book, Brown traces the wobbly contours of the House of Windsor.
content: In her new book, “The Palace Papers,” Tina Brown takes on a centuries-old institution of strong personalities, byzantine rules, a definite pecking order and mercurial public support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Officer Accused of Yanking Mother From S.U.V. During Protest Is Charged
description: The authorities said that Darren Kardos, 42, who has been charged with aggravated assault, pulled a young Black mother out of a vehicle by her hair in October 2020 after she inadvertently found herself near a police barricade during a protest in Philadelphia.
content: A former Philadelphia police officer has been arrested and charged for his role in the assault of a young Black mother who was yanked out of her vehicle after she inadvertently found herself near a police barricade during a protest in October 2020, the city’s district attorney said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Stocks tumble for a third week as jitters over the Fed persist.
description: Friday was the S&P 500’s worst day since early March. Recent comments from Fed officials have fueled expectations that interest rates will climb far faster than anyone had thought.
content: Stocks slid on Friday, with the S&P 500 capping a third consecutive weekly decline as Wall Street quickly changed its expectation for how aggressively the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Tucker Carlson Has a Cure for Declining Virility
description: A promo for an upcoming Fox show describes a testosterone “calamity” among American men, along with an unlikely treatment.
content: Are you a man worried about your testosterone levels? Hoping to give them a boost? Tucker Carlson, the Fox News host, has a solution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Dug in on the front lines, Ukrainian soldiers fight to repel the Russian onslaught.
description: After near-annihilation, and a marriage proposal, a Ukrainian unit has become a group of hardened veterans, dug in and determined.
content: ZAPORIZKA REGION, Ukraine — The day after the war began, after their unit was nearly wiped out in a missile strike, Ukrainian Sgt. Oleksandr Gorvat presented his girlfriend and commanding officer, First Lt. Olena Petyak, a ring he had twisted together from wire and asked for her hand in marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Is Bayern Munich Breaking the Bundesliga?
description: Germany’s perennial champion can secure its 10th straight title this weekend. Even its own fans are starting to worry that its success is getting a little boring.
content: The first time Gregor Weinreich saw Bayern Munich crowned champion of Germany, he celebrated until sunrise. That was 1994. Three years later, when it happened again, he was so euphoric that he ran onto the field at the club’s old Olympic Stadium, a flare burning and sputtering in his hand. He was not alone. Many hundreds more did the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Risking Boos, the Met Opera Puts Present-Day America Onstage
description: A new production of Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor,” directed by Simon Stone, sets the classic work in a fading postindustrial town.
content: Simon Stone paused during a recent rehearsal at the Metropolitan Opera, looked up at the stage, and surveyed his new production of Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor.” Nadine Sierra, singing the title role in a secondhand wedding gown, was preparing to descend the rusting fire escape of an old house for her famous, climactic mad scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Skepticism greets a bold Russian claim about war aims, based on its source.
description: A major shift in policy came from an obscure general and not the president or top commander.
content: When Gen. Rustam Minnekayev made a sweeping statement on Friday that Russia’s next military aim would be to seize Ukraine’s entire southern coast, many analysts were skeptical, based not only on the claim, but on its source.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon light up the dark.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage, which takes place in the deep ocean, reminded me of a recent acrostic excerpt that lyrically described space. Both are pitch black expanses periodically illuminated by traveling orbs; in this case, they’re microscopic organisms — bioluminescent plankton — instead of giant comets and asteroids. This aquatic excerpt comes from a book by Joy Williams titled “The Florida Keys,” which looks like a great armchair travel read about a unique area in North America that includes the only living barrier reef off the continental United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Electric Cars
description: Would you want one? How might they change the auto industry?
content: According to a recent article in The Times, battery-powered cars are having a breakthrough moment and will enter the mainstream this year.  The article continues:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Analysis: The U.S. Appealed to Reinstate Masks. But Is It Seeking to Win?
description: The administration’s actions suggest either a botched case or a shrewd play for time as it gives up on the mask order but hopes to erase an adverse ruling, legal experts said.
content: WASHINGTON — Does the Biden administration really want and intend to fight for a higher court reversal of the ruling this week striking down its mask mandate on airplanes, trains and other public transportation — as its high-profile appeal of the case seemed to suggest?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Philadelphia is ending a short-lived indoor mask mandate.
description: Four days after Philadelphia became the first major American city to reinstate an indoor mask mandate in response to rising coronavirus cases, the city health department announced that the mandate would be lifted because of improving conditions.
content: Four days after Philadelphia became the first major American city to reinstate an indoor mask mandate in response to rising coronavirus cases, the city health department announced that the mandate would be lifted because of improving conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What Makes a Good Job Good?
description: An initiative to define what makes jobs bad or good is long overdue.
content: The United States is producing a lot of jobs, but how many are “good” jobs? That’s hard to know because of a lack of data and because there’s no agreed-upon definition of what makes a job good or bad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: For Gen X, Retirement Bites
description: “Do I have a retirement plan? I hesitate to call it a plan. …” Seven Gen Xers talk about retirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: The ‘Unbelievable, Horrible, Crushing Weight’ of Student Loans
description: And why it doesn’t have to be like this.
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: A Beginner’s Guide to Bouldering
description: People are flocking back to indoor rock climbing gyms for the intense workouts and amiable social scene. It’s not as hard as it looks.
content: The first time John Sherman went rock climbing, he wasn’t some daredevil looking for mountains to conquer. He was a bored teenager wandering the neighborhood a few blocks from his home in Berkeley, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘We Own This City’ Brings George Pelecanos Back to Baltimore
description: The crime novelist broke into TV as a writer on “The Wire.” For his first stint as showrunner, he wanted to get the gang back together one more time.
content: Over the past two years of lockdowns and social distancing, the crime novelist George Pelecanos had plenty to keep him occupied. He estimates that he read roughly 200 books. He watched a lot of Turner Classic Movies and the Criterion Channel. He worked on writing “We Own This City,” the new HBO mini-series he is producing with his longtime creative partner, David Simon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: The Playwright Making a Farce of the Patriarchy
description: “POTUS” will be the writer Selina Fillinger’s Broadway debut. “I really didn’t feel like I needed to do any research. I have been all of those women,” she said.
content: Three days before the first preview performance of her first Broadway production, the playwright Selina Fillinger perched in the middle of the empty mezzanine of the Shubert Theater, peering down upon the set. “I’m sorry, I can’t look away,” she said. “It’s like a crew of fairies and angels, just making things happen.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Love Letter: A Rat and a Reunion
description: There’s nothing like a rodent to bring you closer to your lover’s boyfriend.
content: When a rat fell into her bed, Erin Thompson regretted two things: 1. Keeping her window open, and 2. Choosing to live alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: When Will the Tourists Be Back?
description: An industry weathering a long winter looks warily ahead.
content: An industry weathering a long winter looks warily at the months — or years — ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: The Artist Kenny Scharf Honored at TriBeCa Ball
description: Guests included Brooke Shields, Naomi Watts and Helena Christensen.
content: “I used to think Bob Colacello was the most popular person I knew, but now I think Kenny might be,” said David Kratz, the president of the New York Academy of Art, which honored Kenny Scharf, the artist and contemporary of Keith Haring and Jean-Michel Basquiat, at its TriBeCa Ball on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Leporati
title: Formula 1’s American Conundrum
description: The global motorsport is rapidly expanding in the United States. But when will we see an American driver?
content: When Liberty Media, an American company, purchased Formula 1 in 2017, it made no secret of its ambition to increase the sport’s popularity in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Tyson Fury’s U.K. Boxing Homecoming Is Already Rocked
description: Even before Saturday’s fight at Wembley Stadium in London, the undefeated heavyweight champion was pestered with disruptions.
content: It’s clear that the undefeated heavyweight champion Tyson Fury would prefer that his match Saturday against Dillian Whyte, a former sparring partner, be just about the boxing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: For Panah Panahi, Being the Son of an Iranian Auteur Wasn’t Entirely Helpful
description: He was long paralyzed by the prospect of being compared with Jafar Panahi. But it was his sister who spurred the young director to make his acclaimed new film.
content: The Iranian director Panah Panahi is the son of the embattled auteur Jafar Panahi, who since 2010 has been banned by the Islamic theocracy from making films. But for the younger filmmaker, it was the heartache of being away from his only sibling — along with the collective disillusionment of his compatriots — that informed his debut film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Streamlined Spring Risotto in Shades of Pink and Green
description: A whole bunch of chard adds color and texture, while pancetta lends a porky, salty crunch to a pot of satiny risotto.
content: The day I found out that I didn’t have to stand over the risotto pot, stirring constantly with one hand as I awkwardly ladled in simmering liquid with the other, was the day the rice dish went into my permanent dinner rotation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How Jordan Calhoun, Lifehacker Editor, Spends His Sundays
description: From his basketball league to streaming and playing video games, the new book author makes time to play.
content: Jordan Calhoun has become somewhat of a lifestyle expert in the media world. He is the editor in chief of the how-to website Lifehacker and of the food and pop culture website The Takeout. He also writes the newsletter “Humans Being,” which gleans life lessons from movies, books and television, for The Atlantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and David E. Sanger
title: Hackers Claim to Target Russian Institutions in Barrage of Cyberattacks and Leaks
description: While the authenticity of leaked data could not be verified, the effort appears to be part of a campaign by hackers opposed to the Kremlin.
content: Hackers claim to have broken into dozens of Russian institutions over the past two months, including the Kremlin’s internet censor and one of its primary intelligence services, leaking emails and internal documents to the public in an apparent hack-and-leak campaign that is remarkable in its scope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Shoalts
title: Even on the Glamorous Canadiens, Guy Lafleur Was a Rock Star
description: Not only was Lafleur a prolific goal-scorer, he played hockey the way French Canadian fans loved to see it played, with panache. His death at 70 was announced on Friday.
content: Panache was the word for Guy Lafleur, a towering figure in Montreal hockey history who swooped down the right wing for the Canadiens in the 1970s, golden locks flowing behind, before freezing many a goaltender with his deadly slapshot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: How Arcade Fire Found a Way Back
description: After a meteoric rise that built a passionate fan base, the band had trouble connecting on its last album. A new release, “We,” links the group’s past to its hopes for the future.
content: There are a few indicators that Win Butler, the singer and guitarist who fronts the rock band Arcade Fire, might be a professional somebody: the flat-brimmed, cream-billed bolero hat atop his head or the shock of slicked-back, bleached blond hair that materializes when he takes it off. He’s also exceptionally tall, a trait that helped him to win MVP at the 2016 NBA All-Star Celebrity Game over Jason Sudeikis and Nick Cannon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Aida Alami
title: For France’s Muslims, a Choice Between Lesser Evils in Presidential Vote
description: In Sunday’s decisive runoff election, they have a distasteful choice between Macron and Le Pen. They won’t necessarily back Macron.
content: BONDY, France — Abdelkrim Bouadla voted enthusiastically for Emmanuel Macron five years ago, drawn by his youth and his message of transforming France. But after a presidency that he believes harmed French Muslims like himself, Mr. Bouadla, a community leader who has long worked with troubled young people, was torn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Levenson
title: Russians Seize 42 Towns in Eastern Ukraine as Fighting Intensifies
description: Ukrainian military officials vowed to reverse Russia’s territorial gains in what was turning into a grinding back-and-forth struggle along a front stretching more than 300 miles.
content: Ukrainian officials acknowledged Friday that Russian forces had taken more than three dozen small towns in their initial drive this week to seize eastern Ukraine, offering the first glimpse of what promises to be a grinding brawl by the Kremlin to achieve broader territorial gains in a new phase of the two-month-old war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Labor board issues complaint against Starbucks in firing of 7 workers.
description: The workers had been seeking to unionize a store in Memphis.
content: The National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint against Starbucks on Friday for what the agency said was the unlawful firing of seven employees in Memphis in retaliation for seeking to unionize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Solnit
title: Why Did We Stop Believing That People Can Change?
description: When we see others as the sum of their past beliefs and actions, nothing added, subtracted or transformed, forgiveness and redemption become impossible.
content: My friend Jarvis Masters entered San Quentin prison in 1981 as an angry teenager guilty of numerous counts of armed robbery, and then, with help from a friend on the outside, a new set of ideas and values came his way. Melody Ermachild Chavis, an investigator working on his case, was making her own first forays into Buddhist practice. He embraced what she offered, and it changed him. He became a devoted meditator, then a renowned Tibetan Buddhist practitioner and peacemaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: The Smooch That Sealed the Deal
description: Though Megan O’Conor and Thomas Cordell hit it off right away, it would take several dates before the pair finally had their first kiss.
content: By the end of their first date at Mother Burger, a restaurant in Manhattan’s Hell’s Kitchen neighborhood, in late June 2015, Megan Cunningham O’Conor had sensed something special in Thomas Peter Cordell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: New Zealand Deal May Put Japan Closer to ‘Five Eyes’ Intelligence Alliance
description: The two countries announced a goal of “seamless” sharing of classified information as China moves to expand its influence in the Asia-Pacific region.
content: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — As China moves to expand its influence in the Asia-Pacific region, Japan and New Zealand have opened talks on an agreement for “seamless” sharing of classified information, a step that could strengthen Tokyo’s case to eventually join the “Five Eyes” intelligence partnership among English-speaking powers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A New Day Dawns for Marijuana in New Jersey
description: “I’m very picky when it comes to my weed,” said a customer at a Paterson dispensary on the first day of legal recreational marijuana sales in the state.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll see how things went on the first day of legal marijuana sales in New Jersey. And, because it’s Earth Day, we’ll meet the person who picks trees to plant in city parks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Stephanie Saul
title: A Look Inside the Textbooks That Florida Rejected
description: The state rejected dozens of math textbooks. The New York Times reviewed 21 of them to figure out why.
content: After the Florida Department of Education rejected dozens of math textbooks last week, the big question was, Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan and Nicole Sperling
title: Complaint About Bill Murray Leads Searchlight to Halt Filming of ‘Being Mortal’
description: The suspension happened after an allegation of “inappropriate behavior’’ by the actor, a person involved with the production said.
content: A complaint about “inappropriate behavior” by the actor Bill Murray has led Searchlight Pictures to suspend production of “Being Mortal,” a movie that was written and is being directed by Aziz Ansari, according to a person working on the production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Federal labor board says Activision employees can hold a union election.
description: A group of about 20 quality assurance testers at the video game company are to vote by mail, with ballots counted on May 23.
content: A federal labor board ruled on Friday that a group of about 20 quality assurance workers trying to unionize at Activision Blizzard, the beleaguered video game company, met the requirements to hold a union election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a Polish gangland film recalling “A Clockwork Orange,” an Indonesian fight flick interrogating toxic masculinity and more.
content: In the mobster crime thriller “Furioza,” warring gangs fight with their fists, not guns. The gang of the title is led by Kaszub (Wojciech Zielinski). But it’s his younger brother, Dawid (Mateusz Banasiuk), who interests a ruthless investigator (Lukasz Simlat) and his partner (Weronika Ksiazkiewicz). They want to take down Furioza, and they push Dawid (who left the outfit long ago to become a doctor) to infiltrate the group as an informant or risk his brother going to jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Cleaver
title: Redefining Inclusion for Disabilities That Can Be Harder to See
description: A growing movement among museums, zoos and other attractions aims to expand the idea of accessibility to accommodate people with sensory-processing issues.
content: It wasn’t roaring lions or butting goats that sent 6-year-old Avery Shipley into a tailspin last summer at the Fort Wayne Children’s Zoo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Tries to Sell an Embattled Domestic Agenda During His West Coast Trip
description: President Biden acknowledged that the immediate demands of the presidency, including the pandemic and war in Ukraine, have taken him away from his domestic agenda.
content: SEATTLE — On a trip to the Pacific Northwest this week, President Biden observed the construction of an earthquake-resistant airport runway that had been paid for with funds from a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure law. He unveiled a plan to restore national forests devastated by wildfires. He promoted a climate agenda that has largely gone unfulfilled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: This Game Is Why the Word ‘Jaw-Dropping’ Exists
description: The Memphis Grizzlies were down by more than 20 points — twice — against the Timberwolves in Minnesota but won anyway. And it wasn’t because of their biggest star.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — The job was almost finished, and Memphis Grizzlies guard Desmond Bane looked out across the court, flashed a triumphant smile and wiggled his eyebrows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Do I Reboot My Closet?
description: A reader seeks advice on updating a wardrobe for a new job search.
content: I think this is an issue faced not just by someone starting — or looking for — a new job, but by all of us after two years of working mostly from home. Most workplaces have an unspoken and very unspecific dress code (officially, the line is usually “appropriate” attire), and for most of us that code is derived from a quasi-osmotic processing of being around colleagues and those in positions of power and absorbing the ethos of the institution. We generally end up dressing for the office to be part of the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Mwai Kibaki, Kenya’s Third President, Dies at 90
description: He came to power promising to root out corruption and improve government transparency. But his tenure was blighted by widespread graft and a violent upheaval.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Mwai Kibaki, who helped transform Kenya’s economy and usher in a new Constitution as its third president, but whose tenure was marred by high-profile corruption cases and election-related violence, has died. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Joyce DiDonato Wants Music to ‘Build a Paradise for Today’
description: The star mezzo-soprano’s album and concert program “Eden” addresses climate change by planting seeds both real and metaphorical.
content: What are the duties of an artist toward society? As Russia invades Ukraine, as racism persists in the United States, this age-old question remains very much of the moment. And the list of issues to take a political stand on, whether by choice or suggestion, grows ever longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kory Stamper
title: Lost, and Found, in Translation: 3 Picture Books About Language Turn Anglocentric Tropes on Their Head
description: English is gibberish, “X” is for bear and a shared word is everyone’s cup of tea — in new work by Young Vo, Ellen Heck and Andrea Wang.
content: GIBBERISHBy Young Vo
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Polar Bear’ Review: On Thin Ice
description: This Disneynature documentary traces one female polar bear’s journey from cub to mother.
content: Catherine Keener narrates and acts as a guiding ursine presence in “Polar Bear,” the latest Disneynature documentary to be released on Disney+, just in time for Earth Day. Directed by Alastair Fothergill and Jeff Wilson, the film recounts a female polar bear’s journey from a cub traveling by her mother and brother’s side to being a mother of her own, navigating the ever-shrinking ice flows and seal population that the bears depend on for their survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: At Madison’s Montpelier, a Fight Over Power for Slaves’ Descendants
description: A group has accused the majority-white board that operates the Virginia estate of the nation’s fourth president of thwarting an agreement to share control.
content: Last year, the foundation that runs the sprawling Virginia estate that was the home of President James Madison announced what it called a groundbreaking agreement to share power with a group representing descendants of the hundreds of enslaved workers who built and maintained the plantation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Isabelia Herrera, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Mavis Staples and Levon Helm’s Last Show, and 12 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Pusha T, Laura Veirs, Helado Negro and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany’s economy is expected to contract under a Russian gas embargo.
description: The country’s central bank warned that an abrupt end of gas imports from Russia could cause Germany’s economic output to plunge and inflation to jump.
content: An embargo on Russian natural gas could cause Germany’s economic output to drop as much as 5 percent this year, the Bundesbank warned on Friday, potentially driving the country into a recession while pushing up already high consumer prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How a Recession Might — and Might Not — Happen
description: Goldilocks and the macroeconomic bears.
content: The U.S. economy is still very strong, with, for example, initial claims for unemployment insurance at their lowest point since 1969. Yet everyone is talking about recession. And the truth is that there is a significant chance of recession over the course of the next few years. But do people understand why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1922: Sight of Women Smoking A Cigar Shocks Paris
description: Two women who shared a Havana cigar in a Parisian restaurant reportedly caused a stir.
content: Paris has had plenty of shocks from tourists, but it remained for the present invasion to scandalise Continental society absolutely. It was the advent of cigar-smoking women, not in the quiet corners of their homes, but in a public restaurant. Last night, while Ciro’s was filled to stifling with American visitors, even the waiters gasped when an elderly and matronly woman calmly called for a match, stuck a big black Havana into an amber holder and began to puff contentedly. A few minutes later, a blonde who persisted in talking about her Chicago experiences added to the excitement by borrowing the cigar from the elderly woman and smoking it to the very end. Then, apparently satisfied with the sensation they had caused, both women called for brandy night-caps and escaped from the crowd before their identity could be learned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: One Ukrainian War Casualty: The World’s Largest Airplane
description: Mriya, the world’s largest aircraft, was destroyed in a pivotal battle at the start of the war. It was a beloved symbol for all of Ukraine but perhaps no one misses it more than its first pilot.
content: BUCHA, Ukraine — The day war broke out, one of Ukraine’s most decorated pilots stepped onto the balcony of his three-story home to watch a battle raging at a nearby airport.

author: By Saskia Solomon
title: At 100, the ‘Just William’ Books Are an Icon of British Childhood
description: Richmal Crompton’s prototypical schoolboy has survived war, upheaval, changing tastes and a new world. He’s still just 11.
content: Where to begin with William Brown? The stubbornly disheveled, snub-nosed 11-year-old protagonist of the writer Richmal Crompton’s wildly popular “Just William” stories, 100 this year, is an astutely rendered portrait of a 1920s British schoolboy. His antics — broken drawing-room windows, midnight feasts, theft — have captured the imagination of millions over the decades, the stories adapted for radio, stage and television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: His Gym Made a Harlem Park Special. City Officials Tore It Down.
description: Marcus Garvey Park has been in disrepair for years. Jamel Ali turned a corner of it into an open-air gym.
content: Jamel Ali grew up in East Harlem, but really, he would tell you that he came of age in Marcus Garvey Park, 20 square acres of patchy grass and bruised hardscape surrounded by stately brownstones to the west and institutional looking buildings on upper Madison Avenue. Late one morning this week, I found him where anyone looking would have run into him most days during the past two decades — overseeing an informal training gym, largely of his own creation, occupying a corner of the park in the shadow of Bethel Gospel Assembly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Democrats, You Can’t Ignore the Culture Wars Any Longer
description: The only alternative to fighting is losing.
content: Almost 60 years ago, the historian Richard Hofstadter described what he saw as the true goal of McCarthyism. “The real function of the Great Inquisition of the 1950s was not anything so simply rational as to turn up spies or prevent espionage,” he wrote, “or even to expose actual Communists, but to discharge resentments and frustrations, to punish, to satisfy enmities whose roots lay elsewhere than in the Communist issue itself.”

content: WASHINGTON — Joe Biden was not Vincent Vertuccio’s first choice for president. But as a high school student on Long Island, Mr. Vertuccio organized hundreds of young people to help elect him, driven by a single issue: climate change.

title: Should a Morning Staff Meeting Feel Like Homeroom?
description: A hybrid-work challenge: taking attendance.
content: Hybrid-work arrangements often sound like math equations. Three days a week in the office, two at home; 50 workers commuting into an office of 10,000 square feet and 10 pizzas. It all adds up to 40 hours, somehow — and a logistical challenge for businesses trying to determine whether one part of the solution is keeping track of people’s comings and goings.

author: By Rachel Donadio
title: Macron May Keep the Presidency, but Le Pen Has Already Won
description: The French election has shown the vigor and entrenchment of the far right.
content: SEMUR-EN-AUXOIS, France — Marine Le Pen, the leader of France’s far-right National Rally, has worked hard during this election campaign to soften, even detoxify, her image. It seems to be working. “I think she’s full of good ideas,” Cyrielle Bernard, a 19-year-old who lives in this picturesque Burgundy town, told me one afternoon last week, chatting in the tobacconist shop where she works. Of all the candidates, she said, “I think she’s the most logical.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ursula Bellugi, Pioneer in the World of Sign Language, Dies at 91
description: Her research advanced understanding of the brain and the origins of language — signed and spoken — and shed light on how humans communicate and socialize.
content: Ursula Bellugi, a pioneer in the study of the biological foundations of language who was among the first to demonstrate that sign language was just as complex, abstract and systematic as spoken language, died on Sunday in San Diego. She was 91.

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: For Weary Workers, Video Backdrops Are Becoming Too Close and Personal
description: If your children melt down, or the dirty dishes are visible behind you, does that mean your job performance is chaotic, too?
content: Jillian Amodio has run out of patience for Zoom. The whole window-into-your-private-life experiment was novel in the early, chaotic days of the pandemic, when it was almost a badge of honor if your children melted down onscreen or your cat made a cameo. But those days are gone, and by now most people have invested in a ring light or, at the very least, mastered the virtual background.

content: SEOUL — South Korea’s departing president, Moon Jae-in, exchanged farewell letters with North Korea’s dictator, Kim Jong-un, both governments announced on Friday, capping a checkered relationship filled with highs and lows and currently locked in a diplomatic stalemate.​
